subCategories.title: Accessability
subCategories.description: ILIAS takes accessability seriously. Accessability guidelines presented in this section MUST be followed if new elements are added.

subCategories.title: Less
subCategories.description: ILIAS uses less as css pre-processor. This section introduces all used less variables and guidelines of less.

subCategories.title: Visualizations
subCategories.description: Visualizations to display the structure of less and entry dependencies.

items.title: Base Counter

description.content: Counters inform users about the quantity of items indicated by a glyph.
Counters consist of a number and some background color and are placed on the ‘end of the line’ in reading direction of the item they state the count for.
Counters convey information, they are not interactive.
Counters inform users about the quantity of items indicated by a glyph.

rules: A Counter MUST only be used in combination with a glyph.
A Counter MUST contain exactly one number greater than zero and no other characters.

items.title: Novelty Counter

description.content: Novelty counters inform users about the arrival or creation of new items of the kind indicated by the accompanying glyph.
The Novelty Counter is an obtrusive counter.
They count down  / disappear as soon as the change has been consulted by the user.

rules: There MUST be a way for the user to consult the changes indicated by the Counter. After the consultation, the Novelty Counter SHOULD disappear or the number it contains is reduced by one. Depending on the content, the reduced number might be added in an additional Status Counter.
The Novelty Counter MUST be displayed on the top at the ‘end of the line’ in reading direction of the item it accompanies. This would be top right for latin script and top left for arabic script.
The Novelty Counter SHOULD have an obtrusive background color such as red or orange.
MAY be used together with the Status Counter.

items.title: Status Counter

description.content: The Status Counter is used to display information about the total number of some items like users active on the system or total amount of comments.
The Status Counter is a non-obtrusive Counter.
Status Counters convey information, they are not interactive.

rules: The Status Counter MUST be displayed on the lower right of the item it accompanies.
The Status Counter SHOULD have an non-obtrusive background color such as grey.

items.title: Base Modal

description.content: The Modal forces users to focus on the task at hand.
A Modal is a full-screen dialog on top of the greyed-out ILIAS screen. The Modal consists of a header with a close button and a typography modal title, a content section and might have a footer.
All controls of the original context are inaccessible until the Modal is completed. Upon completion the user returns to the original context.

Modals have some relations to popovers. The main difference between the two is the disruptive nature of the Modal and the larger amount of data that might be displayed inside a modal. Also popovers perform mostly action to add or consult metadata of an item while Modals manipulate or focus items or their sub-items directly.

featureWikiReferences: DR 5.1 - Issue 02: Keep Drop-Downs in Viewport / Overlay handling
rules: The main purpose of the Modals MUST NOT be navigational. But Modals MAY be dialogue of one or two steps and thus encompass “next”-buttons  or the like.
Modals MUST NOT contain other modals (Modal in Modal).
Modals SHOULD not be used to perform complex workflows.
Modals MUST be closable by a little “x”-button on the right side of the header.
Modals MUST contain a title in the header.

items.title: Round-Trip Modal

description.content: Round-Trip Modals are to be used if the context would be lost by performing this action otherwise. Round-Trip Modals accommodate sub-workflows within an overriding workflow. The Round-Trip Modal ensures that the users does not leave the trajectory of the overriding workflow. This is typically the case if an ILIAS service is called for while in working in an object.
Round-Trip Modals are completed by a small well defined sequence of 2 steps max. that might be displayed on a sequence of different modals connected through some “next” Button.
Round-Trip Modals perform sub-workflow involving some kind of user input. Sub-workflow is completed and user is returned to starting point allowing for continuing the overriding workflow.

items.context: Adding an Internal Link in the ILIAS Page Editor is done with a Modal. The overriding workflow is “page editing” the sub-workflow is “adding internal link”.
rules: Round-Trip Modals MUST contain at least two buttons at the bottom of the modals: a button to cancel (right) the workflow and a button to finish or reach the next step in the workflow (left).

Round-Trip Modals SHOULD be used, if the user would lose the context otherwise. If the action can be performed within the same context (e.g. add a post in a forum, edit a wiki page), a Round-Trip Modal MUST NOT be used.
When the workflow is completed, Round-Trip Modals SHOULD show the same view as was displayed when initiating the Modal.
Round-Trip Modals SHOULD NOT be used to add new items of any kind since adding item is a linear workflow redirecting to the newly added item setting- or content-tab.
Round-Trip Modals SHOULD NOT be used to perform complex workflows.

items.title: Interruptive Modal

description.content: An Interruptive Modal disrupts the user in critical situation, forcing him or her to focus on the task at hand.
The Modal states why this situation needs attention and may point out consequences.
All controls of the original context are inaccessible until the Modal is completed. Upon completion the user returns to the original context.

items.context: Interruptive Modals are currently used to submit or delete answers in a test before turning to using the test-related controls.
rules: Due to the heavily disruptive nature of this type of Modal it MUST be restricted to critical situations (e.g. loss of data).
All delete-actions are critical situations and MUST be implemented as an Interruptive Modal.

Interruptive Modals MUST contain a Default Button continuing the action that initiated the Modal (e.g. Delete the Item) on the left side of the footer of the modal and a button canceling the action on the right side of the footer as Default Button.
The Cancel Button in the footer and the Close Button in the header MUST NOT perform any additional action than closing the confirmation screen.

items.title: Lightbox Modal

description.content: The Lightbox Modal displays a full of data such as documents, images or a movie inside a Lightbox.
If multiple pages or images are to be displayed in one Lightbox Modal, they can flipped through.
Lightbox Modals are activated by clicking the Full View Glyphicon, the Title of the object or it’s Thumbnail.
Preview Popovers have some relation to Lightbox Modals. Preview Popovers only display parts or a reduced level of detail of the data to be previewed while Lightbox Modals display a complete view.

items.context: Mediacast Objects are presented inside a Lightbox Modals.
rules: Lightbox Modals MUST contain a Closing Button on the top right and a title above the presented item.
Lightobx Modals MUST contain a title above the presented item.
Lightbox Modals SHOULD contain a descriptional text below the presented items.
Multiple images or pages inside a Lightbox Modals MUST be presented in carousel like manner allowing to flickr through items.

items.title: Form

description.content: Forms are used for creating content of sub-items or for configuring objects or services.
A form is divided into areas which are further divided into sections containing settings with selection or input controls.
Users manipulate input in settings and save the form to apply the settings to the object or service.

items.context: Forms are usually placed in a tabbed content area.
rules: Each form MUST contain at least one titled form section.
Forms MUST NOT be used on the same content screen as tables.
Forms MUST NOT be used on the same content screen as toolbars.

items.title: Titled Form Section

description.content: A titled form section subdivides a form allowing users to browse the screen. Titled Form Sections are stacked. The stacking reflects perceived relevance and  is kept consistent across objects thus learners are “familiar” with forms.
At least one titled form section is used in every form. A title states the purpose shared by all settings of the titled form section. The section visually groups settings.
This element has no effect in terms of clicking.

items.background: Tidwell ‘Designing Interfaces’ proposed the pattern of ‘Titled Sections’ and describes it as: “Define separate sections of content by giving each one a visually strong title, separating the sections visually, … “. She further explains that those section should be grouped by topic or task. According to Tidwell is content that is sectioned neatly into chunks easier to grasp since the human visual system is always looking for bigger patterns. In ILIAS such sections in a form are called titled form sections.
items.context: All settings-tabs in ILIAS contain forms. Most of the administration panel is made of forms. Putting content into sub-items oftentimes makes use of forms i.e. putting content into a test question.
rules: A Titled Form Section MUST contain a title.
The title SHOULD summarize the contained settings accurately from a user’s perspective.
The title SHOULD contain less than 30 characters.
The titles MUST be cross-checked with similar forms in other objects or services to ensure consistency throughout ILIAS.
In doubt consistency in titles SHOULD be prioritized over accuracy.
Proper Titled Form Sections SHOULD comprise 2 to 5 Settings.
More than 5 Settings SHOULD be split into two areas unless this would tamper with the “familiar” information architecture of forms.
There MUST NOT be a Setting without an enclosing Titled Form Section. If necessary a Titled Form Section MAY contain only one single Setting.
The first and last titled form section of a form MUST contain a “Save” and “Cancel” button for the form. “Save” is left and “Cancel” is right.

In some rare exceptions the buttons MAY be named differently: if “Save” or “Cancel”  are clearly a misleading since the action is more than storing the data into the database. “Send Mail” would be an example of this.

items.title: Form Setting

description.content: A setting is used to collect one specific piece of information from the  user.
A setting is composed of an identifier on the left and an input element on the right. It may contain a by-line (explanatory text) below the input element.
The effect depends on the control-type of the input element.

items.context: Settings are used in forms of the settings-tab, in forms of the administration panel and when üputting content into a sub-item.
rules: A setting MUST contained by a Titled Form Section.
A setting MUST use an identifier and an input element.
An identifier MUST be composed of one single term or a very short phrase. The identifier is an eye catcher for users skimming the form.
An identifier MUST avoid lingo. Intelligibility by occasional users is prioritized over technical accuracy. The accurate technical expression is to be mentioned in the by-line.
An identifier MUST make a positive statement. If the purpose of the setting is inherently negative, use Verbs as “Limit..”, “Lock..”.
Wording and structure (sequence and control) MUST be consistent with identifiers in other objects. If you feel a wording needs to be changed, then you MUST propose it to the JF.

A by-line (explanatory text) MAY be added below the input element on the right side. If by-lines are provided they MUST be informative, not merely repeating the identifier’s or input element’s content. If no informative description can be devised, no description is needed.
A by-line MUST clearly state what effect the Setting produces and explain, why this might be important and what it can be used for.
A by-line MUST be placed directly underneath the option it describes. Bulk by-lines underneath a stack of option explaining all of the options in one paragraph MUST NOT be used.
A by-line SHOULD NOT address the user directly. Addressing users directly is reserved for cases of high risk of severe mis-configuration.
A by-line MUST be grammatically complete sentence with a period (.) at the end.
By-lines SHOULD be short with no more than 25 words.
By-lines SHOULD NOT use any formatting in descriptions (bold, italic or similar).

If by-lines refer to other tabs or options or tables by name, that reference should be made in quotation marks:  ‘Info’-tab /  "Info"-Reiter, button ‘Show Test Results’ / Button "Testergebnisse anzeigen",  ‘Table of Detailed Test Results’  /  "Tabelle mit detaillierten Testergebnissen". Use proper quotation marks, not apostrophs. Use single quotation marks for english language and double quotation maks for german language.
By-lines MUST NOT feature parentheses since they greatly diminish readability.

By-lines SHOULD NOT start with terms such as: If this option is set …, If this setting is active …, Choose this setting if … or This setting …. Rather state what happens directly: Participants get / make  / can …, Point in time after which… or ILIAS will monitor ….

items.title: Form Subsetting

description.content: Settings can be nested allowing for settings-dependent further configuration.
Subsettings are underneath the Setting they depend on. The Subsetting is indented to visually confirm said dependence.
Subsettings are revealed after enabling the selection control of a setting. If the setting is not enabled, the subsetting remains hidden.

rules: Subsetting MUST NOT be enabled by any other form element than a checkbox or a radio input group.
Subsettings MUST bear an identifier.
Subsettings of a setting can be stacked. The most relevant subsetting MUST be the first subsetting in the stack. The least relevant comes last in the stack.

There MUST NOT be a nesting of more than one subsetting (see Jour Fixe comment in feature wiki reference). The only exception to this rule is the required quantification of a subsetting by a date or number. These exceptions MUST individually accepted by the Jour Fixe.
